5.text:
Jennifer Scott:– We now move on to our next
speaker, who will be with us just in one moment,

9.text:
who is Sarah Grant, who is the Curator of
Prints at the Victoria and Albert Museum.

15.text:
Now Sarah has published widely on prints of
the eighteenth century and she’ll be…

20.text:
Actually we’re really lucky that she’s
with us today because she’s immensely tired

24.text:
having submitted her PhD thesis yesterday.
So it’s a terrific thing that she’s here

29.text:
to share her research with us today.
And it is new research. And her topic today

34.text:
is actually looking at the court around Marie-Antoinette,
so she’s looking at the senior French courtier,

41.text:
the princesse de Lamballe, who was the close
and long-standing confidante to Marie-Antoinette.

46.text:
And this new research is presented on the
sympathetic elite community that sprang up

51.text:
between the travelling members of the English
‘Ton’, and key members of the French court

56.text:
during the late eighteenth century, the French
queen’s own anglophile inclinations and

61.text:
perceptible correlations in the portraits,
both the groups and commissioned.

66.text:
So I’m really excited to hear this topic
today and to hear what Sarah’s going to

70.text:
share with us about it.
Sarah Grant:– The reign of Marie-Antoinette

74.text:
and Queen Charlotte witnessed a social and
cultural and artistic rapprochement between

80.text:
France and Britain that was entirely without
precedent.

84.text:
And during the 1780s and 1770s, the French
began to cross the Channel in greater numbers

89.text:
than ever before. Of course, the English had
always travelled south and, to get to the

93.text:
Continent, they had to go through France.
But this was quite exceptional for the French

98.text:
to suddenly start visiting London and the
counties in these numbers.

102.text:
And one such person was the Italian-born princesse
de Lamballe, and she is largely forgotten

108.text:
today. She’s really only remembered for
the way that she died, which was being decapitated

115.text:
and torn limb from limb by the Paris mob during
the revolutionary September Massacres. Her

122.text:
head was placed on a pike and paraded in front
of the Tuileries Palace where Marie-Antoinette

127.text:
and Louis XVI were imprisoned.
But she, in life, served as superintendent

132.text:
of Marie-Antoinette’s household, and that
was the highest position that a female courtier

137.text:
could aspire to obtain. She was also an influential
patron and cultural figure at the French court

142.text:
and she had a very important collection. And
she was also a bibliophile, she was a musical

147.text:
patron, she was all sorts of different things.
Just five years before her tragic demise,

153.text:
the princesse made a three month visit to
England. And she also returned a second time

158.text:
in 1791, but as a fugitive.
But this paper is going to focus on that first

163.text:
visit in 1787 which was effectively a Grand
Tour in reverse. It was conducted when French

170.text:
anglomania was at its height. And the portraits,
official and unofficial, produced of her,

176.text:
I’ll touch on in this paper.
But I’m also going to discuss her fellow

179.text:
anglophile who was partner in all of these
anglophile interests, and that was her mistress,

184.text:
Marie-Antoinette. And talk a little bit about
Marie-Antoinette’s collection of English

187.text:
prints which were - many of them - portraits.
And a sympathetic elite community that can

192.text:
be seen to have sprung up between the queen
and her courtiers and travelling members of

197.text:
the English ‘Ton’ during the last few
decades of the eighteenth century, and discussing

201.text:
some of the resulting perceptible correlations
in the portraits that both groups commissioned.

206.text:
So I’m showing you here two official portraits
of the princesse de Lamballe. The one on the

209.text:
left by Vigée-Lebrun and the one on the right
by Joseph Ducreux which showed her after she’d

216.text:
been appointed as superintendent and after
she’d really started to sort of grow in

220.text:
profile and status at the French court. And
develop an international reputation across

224.text:
Europe but also in the States as well, and
in England, of course.

229.text:
So even before her visit in 1787 she was already
an established anglophile. She grew up in

237.text:
Turin as a princess of a cadet branch of the
house of Savoy, Savoy-Carignan princess. And

243.text:
the House of Savoy was noted, and the court
in Turin as well, for its hunting prowess

249.text:
and her father had all his hounds shipped
over from England. There’s a bill that survives

253.text:
that documents this.
So I’m just showing you here a slide of

255.text:
Stupinigi which is the hunting, the beautiful
hunting palace, just on the outskirts of Turin

260.text:
which is where she spent her summers. So she
was already familiar with all things English

264.text:
at that stage.
But she also had in France an extensive English

268.text:
garden landscaped in the grounds of one of
father-in-law’s 34 chateaux. He was the

274.text:
second richest man in France after the king,
Rambouillet, and this was the print that was

279.text:
published down the bottom right of her English
garden. And it actually features a hidden

284.text:
portrait of the princess as well here on the
see-saw. That’s her. And she was also shown…

291.text:
She’s miraculously see-sawing herself here,
there’s no counterweight. This is the little

297.text:
cottage that she had in the garden. This is
one of only two structures that remains in

302.text:
the garden today and you can see the man-made
sort of stream, river that was placed… But

309.text:
you can see some of the other parts, there’s
the Hermitage as well which is also still

314.text:
there, it’s just been conserved.
But the fact that her English garden was published

319.text:
in this very famous series of prints by Le
Rouge, who was a surveyor, shows that it was

324.text:
considered a paradigm of an English garden
in Paris. And she was one of only a couple

330.text:
of people who are actually shown in the prints
of their own gardens. So she’s shown as

334.text:
mistress of her domain in this particular
print.

339.text:
She also had two other English gardens created
in the grounds of her country house outside

343.text:
Paris for which she enlisted the talents of
Thomas Blaikie.

347.text:
But when she arrived on these shores…
And that’s her, that’s just a close-up

351.text:
of her see-sawing away, her little dog observing
her down in the corner, and then that’s

356.text:
her on the swing as well at Rambouillet.
But when she arrived on these shores in July

362.text:
of 1787 the princesse de Lamballe, with the
exception of her brother-in-law, the duc d'Orléans,

368.text:
was the highest ranking French courtier of
Louis XVI’s court who had ever visited England.

372.text:
So as one of Marie-Antoinette’s closest
friends, and arguably her personal emissary

377.text:
and agent, her arrival could be, and very
likely was, interpreted as the closest approximation

383.text:
to a state visit from the queen of France
herself.

387.text:
She survived the Channel crossing from Calais,
which was a notoriously unpredictable, occasionally

391.text:
treacherous, journey of 10 to 12 hours. And
she landed at Dover in great style flanked

398.text:
by a 40-strong retinue of ladies-in-waiting
and attendants. From here she went on by coach,

404.text:
arriving in London on the 10 July, where she
took up residence in the very heart of the

408.text:
city at Grenier’s Hotel on Jermyn Street.
Her arrival caused a sensation. It sent the

415.text:
English press into a frenzy and all the ‘Ton’
a-chatter, and people who weren’t invited

419.text:
to various events that were held for her were
very upset and that included Horace Walpole.

424.text:
Every activity she engaged in was closely
scrutinised and her progress from city to

428.text:
city across the country was followed by the
journals of the time.

431.text:
A series of splendid entertainments were staged
for her. There was a grand rout held by Sir

436.text:
Peter Burrell who was the Lord Chamberlain
and Member of Parliament at his house in Whitehall.

441.text:
And then there was an outing to the Royal
Academy at Woolwich to view the royal artillery

444.text:
which was a spectacle clearly devised by the
English host to signal to their French guest

448.text:
the superiority of the British Navy.
Here the princess was accompanied by the Duke

453.text:
of Richmond, the Duchess of Devonshire, Lady
Dungannon, and other ladies of distinction.

457.text:
She supped with George III and Queen Charlotte
at Kew, and she attended a sumptuous dinner

462.text:
given in her honour by the Duke of Queensbury.
She then departed London on a tour of the

467.text:
country which sounds rather like, if anybody’s
done it, the Attingham Country House course.

473.text:
She visited Tonbridge Wells, Brighton, Bath,
and Oxford, and all the time viewing country

479.text:
houses and collections along the way, including
Blenheim Palace and Broadlands, Lord Palmerston’s

484.text:
seat near Romsey where Capability Brown had
refaced the house in the Palladian style.

489.text:
The princess also viewed Lord Spencer’s
collection, either at Althorp or Spencer House

494.text:
in London.
These visits to country houses I think are

498.text:
very significant for these were arguably the
nation’s finest treasure houses and once

502.text:
a backdrop to and purveyor of English identity.
And through her tours the princess would have

508.text:
both expressed and consolidated her interest
in English art. But she would also have encountered,

513.text:
most importantly, a wealth of English portraits,
the focal point of any country house, where

519.text:
a hall, gallery or some other form of reception
room is given over to the sequential display

523.text:
of dynastic power and continuity.
Finally, having seen everything she could

528.text:
that was the highlight of the whole country,
she left on 11 October after three month’s

533.text:
sojourn, an exhaustive Anglo Grand Tour, and
embarked on the journey home.

538.text:
But towards the very beginning of her stay,
she sat for Richard Cosway in a portrait that

543.text:
was rumoured at the time to be a gift intended
for her friend, the Prince of Wales. Richard

549.text:
Cosway and his wife, Maria, were then the
most fashionable portrait painters in London.

554.text:
Not only was Cosway official painter to the
Prince of Wales, but he was also a noted favourite

558.text:
of the influential Duchess of Devonshire,
his first important patron. And the couple

562.text:
cultivated a French clientele.
Cosway captured the likeness of a number of

567.text:
French sitters from the queen’s circle,
Queen Marie-Antoinette’s circle, including

571.text:
Lamballe’s brother-in-law, the duc d'Orléans,
and two of the queen’s closest friends,

574.text:
the Princesse de Tarente and the duchesse
de Polignac.

578.text:
And here comes the disclaimer I’m afraid,
because the portrait of Lamballe is now lost

582.text:
regrettably. It showed up briefly in a sale
at Christie’s in the 1950s, but for some

587.text:
reason they didn’t take a photograph so
it was regrettably unillustrated. But the

592.text:
princess was described as being shown nearly
full-face, her head inclined to her left shoulder.

597.text:
So it’s two miniatures and drawings of an
equivalent date by Cosway of French sitters

602.text:
including the duchesse de Polignac here, who
was Lamballe’s greatest rival at court,

608.text:
they absolutely loathed each other. And then
this is her, the duchess’s sister-in-law,

613.text:
the comtesse de Polignac. And then this is
Cosway’s beautiful, beautiful miniature

617.text:
of Madame du Barry who was Louis XV’s last
mistress and who was guillotined in the revolution.

624.text:
And then another portrait, just this time
of the Duchess of Devonshire, just to give

628.text:
an indication of the sort of portrait that
she might have had when she sat for Cosway.

632.text:
It’s probably most likely that it was a
pencil drawing because these were… Well,

636.text:
actually in pencil or miniature, because they
were both portable. But seemingly French sitters

641.text:
often had drawings like this.
By the 1780s, the French had come to see the

649.text:
genres of portraiture and landscape as quintessentially
English. And the motivations driving these

654.text:
commissions by French visitors, including
the princesse de Lamballe, were probably to

658.text:
procure a souvenir commemorating their visit,
one being painted by a native artist that

663.text:
would contain an element of novelty to amuse
the French court with on their return. Second,

668.text:
to be seen demonstrating their connoisseurship
and general largesse by extending their patronage

672.text:
to an artist judged of fashionable standing.
And third to create for the benefit of their

678.text:
new circle, their new English circle, and
expressed in that country’s visual idiom

682.text:
a representation, that would all the better
assume currency and weight for its stylistic

686.text:
resemblance to its own.
All members of the princesse de Lamballe’s

690.text:
English circle had had their portraits done
by Cosway several times over. And so the princesse

696.text:
de Lamballe’s commission enabled her to
make a gift of her own image to a prince renowned

700.text:
in England for his artistic patronage by an
artist with whom he had a strong association.

707.text:
An unofficial portrait was created of the
princess during her visit in the form of a

711.text:
Wedgewood Jasperware cameo. This was for the
series of heads of illustrious or famous personages,

717.text:
which incidentally we know from a surviving
inventory, that the princess collected herself.

722.text:
Wedgewood was very impatient for them all
to be completed as he hoped to capitalise

726.text:
on the extraordinary interest of the princess
fuelled by her presence in the country. He

730.text:
also advertised the cameo in his French-language
edition of his famous catalogue, marketing

736.text:
it to a French audience as well as an English
one.

739.text:
And the cameo was so popular… And here it
is here, it says ‘Princesse de Lamballe’

745.text:
in the legend. It was so popular that a second
larger variation in black basalt was created.

751.text:
But these are sadly today considerably rarer
than the Jasperware ones.

755.text:
So again I’m showing you… This is Marie-Antoinette’s
Wedgewood cameo that Wedgewood produced and

761.text:
then this is the black basalt version, so
it would have been a black basalt version

765.text:
like this of Lamballe. And they were usually
after medals and in this case it was - the

771.text:
queen’s one was after a medal - so Lamballe’s
would also have been as well.

778.text:
From the same inventory I mentioned, we learn
of the princess’s enthusiasm for English

782.text:
prints. She had displays of these in two of
her houses. In one suite of rooms, of the

788.text:
40 prints that were framed and displayed,
26 were English. So from this description

792.text:
it’s clear that these were stipple prints
(from the descriptions in the inventory, it’s

796.text:
clear). Many are from Angelica Kauffman and
works by other famous practitioners like Bartolozzi,

802.text:
and a number of portraits.
English prints became very popular in Paris

805.text:
during the late-1770s and throughout the 1780s.
And one of the most popular categories was

813.text:
the portrait print. This was an interest that
the princess shared with Marie-Antoinette.

818.text:
And this is her house in Passy, which was
then a small country village but it’s now

823.text:
obviously a suburb of Paris. And it was a
country house, so that was part of the reason

828.text:
that she showed English prints in her country
house because that was appropriate to the

833.text:
setting.
So a surviving set of bills reveals the extent

839.text:
of Marie-Antoinette’s acquisitions of English
prints and English portrait prints in particular.

844.text:
They detail orders of prints and books for
her rooms at Versailles covering the period

848.text:
1784 to 1788 and so were therefore just a
portion of the acquisitions she made while

853.text:
in residence. But they total thousands of
livres across this four year period, a time

858.text:
frame that neatly coincides with the princesse
de Lamballe’s visit to England in 1787.

864.text:
So from this we have to conclude that the
courtier’s visit and subsequent reports

868.text:
of her journey in England helped to strengthen
Marie-Antoinette’s already active anglomania.

873.text:
Recurring themes among the queen’s prints
are maternal and romantic love, and scenes

878.text:
of rural pleasures and domestic bliss. So,
for instance in 1784, she acquired honest,

883.text:
fresh-faced country characters like ‘Patty’,
this one on the left, and ‘The Country Maid’,

888.text:
after Bunbury and some of the more domestic
ones after Philip Mercier’s ‘Domestic

894.text:
Employment’, and then ‘Affection and Innocence’
as well, one of Bartolozzi’s prints.

900.text:
Many of her purchases, Marie-Antoinette’s,
were made the same year, or within a few months

905.text:
even, of the print being published in London.
And they reveal her desire to know and understand

910.text:
English sociability and indicate a running
familiarity with current events and topical

915.text:
figures across the Channel.
So, for instance, she was very interested,

919.text:
clearly, in famous contemporary English figures,
and feats of female heroism and fortitude

924.text:
evidently appealed to her. So she had this
print of Lady Harriet Acland who was famous

929.text:
for crossing enemy lines in the midst of the
American revolutionary wars to locate her

933.text:
gravely wounded husband and minister to him.
And she also was not above a few jokes, Marie-Antoinette

939.text:
had a sense of humour. She acquired an impression
of Samuel Fores’s satirical print of the

944.text:
Prince of Wales, the Royal Academy, in which
in his shown boxing the soldier George Hanger.

949.text:
And she also acquired a caricature of the
prince’s secret wedding to Mrs Fitzherbert.

953.text:
Of greater import for this study, however,
were the queen’s purchases of portrait prints.

962.text:
These included portrait prints of sitters
she knew of, like George III with his family,

967.text:
and a full-length portrait of the Prince of
Wales. But she also had prints of individuals

971.text:
outside her circle of acquaintance which she
would have acquired as examples of the work

975.text:
of fashionable English artists or were critically
appraised as paradigms of the British school.

981.text:
And one such example is a print described
as a portrait of Colonel Tarleton which must

985.text:
be Reynolds’s famously dashing evocation
of the young soldier who commanded British

990.text:
troops in the American War of Independence.
Tarleton would of course have been a figure

994.text:
of great curiosity to Marie-Antoinette, but
the portrait had also been very well received

998.text:
by critics, and she would no doubt have been
eager to see a work by an artist whose work

1002.text:
was followed with such interest in France.
She also had a portrait of the family of the

1006.text:
Duke of Marlborough, possibly a print after
Reynolds’s monumental 1777 portrait of the

1013.text:
family painted at Blenheim. Or, perhaps, Bartolozzi’s
affecting depiction of the fourth duke with

1019.text:
his wife, Lady Caroline, and his third born
son, Francis. It’s not quite clear from

1024.text:
the inventory description which one it might
have been.

1028.text:
Another portrait in her collection was of
the Duchess of Richmond. So she had this portrait

1032.text:
of her in Turkish dress. And she also acquired
a large number of portraits by John Sherwin

1038.text:
and other artists of famous actresses and
players, so Sarah Siddons, Elizabeth Hartley,

1043.text:
Elizabeth Sheridan, Frances Abington, and
Mary Robinson.

1046.text:
And she bought two portrait prints of the
Duchess of Devonshire in April 1784, one by

1051.text:
Bartolozzi, and a second entitled ‘The Children
of the Duchess of Devonshire’. The former

1059.text:
work might be one by the noble amateur Diana
Beauclerc showing the duchess in profile but

1066.text:
more likely, given the time frame, it was
probably Bartolozzi’s print here after James

1071.text:
Nixon.
And the other one is harder to track down

1076.text:
because at the time Georgina only had one
child, but the print is described as a print

1080.text:
of ‘her children’. So was it perhaps a
mistake on the part of the clerk? Was it referring

1085.text:
to an earlier print showing Georgina’s mother
with her child? It’s not entirely clear,

1090.text:
but anyway it was a Duchess of Devonshire.
At the time there existed a brisk trade in

1096.text:
French and English portrait prints in both
capitals, and in London, collectors were offered

1101.text:
English prints after French portraits of French
sitters. There were a huge number of English

1107.text:
prints after French portraits of Marie-Antoinette
and the other women of her circle as well,

1111.text:
and in particular the comtesse d’Artois
and the comtesse de Provence who were, in

1116.text:
fact, Lamballe’s cousins once removed.
And I could have shown you a really huge number

1120.text:
of examples here but I’ve just honed it
down to two.

1126.text:
With this concrete evidence of Marie-Antoinette’s
purchases of English portrait prints and the

1130.text:
highly active commercial trade of portrait
prints in mind, it becomes clear that the

1134.text:
queen and Lamballe had a ready familiarity
with, and interest in, English portraiture

1139.text:
that complemented their more general anglophile
persuasions.

1142.text:
The same can be asserted with regard to French
portraits. For their well-travelled English

1147.text:
friends and Francophiles, the Duchess of Devonshire
and Lady Elizabeth Foster, and together with

1152.text:
duchesse de Polignac, this was a small fellowship
of women. And poses an ideal subject for examining

1157.text:
links between the two schools of female portraiture
in France and England at this time, because

1162.text:
really this was an unprecedented sorority
united by many shared interests and experiences

1167.text:
creating a unique forum for culture and artistic
exchange.

1172.text:
Scholars have understandably shied away from
the problematic task of effecting comparisons

1176.text:
between French and British portraits, particularly
in light of their substantially different

1180.text:
apparatus and the instruments of artistic
instruction and patronage. Nor do art historians

1185.text:
generally examine different schools with sweeping
parallels, considering this practice fraught

1191.text:
with possible pitfalls, and you’ll have
to tell me what you think.

1194.text:
But a general influence of the French school
on English portrait painters and vice versa

1198.text:
has continued to be discerned by successive
art historians over the past three decades.

1204.text:
And so given the abundant overlap between
the elite societies of this time, in particular

1208.text:
the circles of Lamballe and Devonshire (the
Duchess of Devonshire), it seemed logical

1212.text:
to conclude that something may be learned
from comparing the cross-channel portraits

1217.text:
they commissioned.
Even a cursory comparison of this now iconic

1222.text:
portrait of Marie-Antoinette with a Rose by
Vigée-Lebrun, and an equally famous portrait

1227.text:
of the Duchess of Devonshire by Gainsborough,
reveals a striking resemblance in prose and

1231.text:
format, if not the brushwork and handling.
The ethereal dresses and hats, the positioning

1237.text:
of their hands, and the pink rose held by
both sitters, the benevolently regal gaze,

1243.text:
even the rakish tilts of their plumed hats
are all remarkable similarities.

1247.text:
The queen’s portrait was painted in 1783
and was exhibited in the Paris Salon that

1253.text:
year, a hastily executed substitute for a
virtually identical portrait, ‘en chemise’

1259.text:
or ‘en gaulle’, which the artist was forced
to withdraw following a public outcry at its

1264.text:
perceived impropriety and I’m sure everybody’s
familiar with the story of the muslin dress

1268.text:
that people felt was not appropriate attire
for a queen.

1273.text:
Despite this initial reaction, the much maligned
muslin dress portrait of Marie-Antoinette

1277.text:
became something of a succès de scandale,
and the essential elements of this portrait

1281.text:
and its replacement went on to be widely copied
in the portraiture of the time.

1286.text:
The Gainsborough portrait was executed four
years later in 1787, but unfortunately it’s

1291.text:
not documented in Chatsworth archives. In
fact none of the Duchess’s portrait commissions

1295.text:
are. And not only has its history been obfuscated
by its long disappearance from that collection

1300.text:
and subsequent theft - it was only returned
to Chatsworth in 1994 - but attention has

1305.text:
not unnaturally concentrated on this sensational
second life, and not on illuminating the circumstances

1312.text:
of its execution.
It’s not only possible but entirely likely

1316.text:
that Lady Elizabeth Foster saw one or all
versions of Vigée-Lebrun’s portrait of

1320.text:
the queen during her 1785 visit to Versailles.
And she and Georgiana cannot have failed to

1325.text:
be aware of the fracas that surrounded the
portrait’s first presentation to the public.

1330.text:
It may even have appealed to the duchess’s
playful sense of humour to base her own portrait

1334.text:
along similar lines.
And considering the proliferation of Vigée-Lebrun

1338.text:
portraits at this time and that art is a considerable
thing, the duchess may have sought to realise

1344.text:
aspects of the sophisticated template modelled
beguilingly by Marie-Antoinette, but judiciously

1349.text:
through the moderating lens of her peculiarly
English sensibility.

1355.text:
The princesse de Lamballe, the duchesse de
Polignac, The Duchess of Devonshire, and Lady

1359.text:
Elizabeth, I should come up with some sort
of acronym for them all, were all devotees

1363.text:
of the double friendship portrait, a format
pioneered by French artists.

1368.text:
A double portrait of the duchess and Lady
Elizabeth Foster, here, which is in The Wallace

1375.text:
Collection, was executed by the French miniaturist,
Guérin, on one of their two visits together

1380.text:

1450.text:
So some of these similarities of course can
be ascribed to common fashions. In England,

1456.text:
French dress had long been considered superior
to domestic products with the exception of

1460.text:

France, Anglomania had brought with it an

1464.text:

specifically ‘country’, fashions. Marie-Antoinette

1469.text:

to Georgiana and is generally accepted as

1474.text:

to corresponding English circles.

1478.text:
While English gloves and plumed hats, as modelled

1483.text:

taken up by the queen and her courtiers.

1493.text:

1497.text:

So I show you here this portrait here by Reynolds
